conversation.message: Dear Nursery_B Admissions Team, I’m Parent_D and Nursery_B is my first-choice nursery. I’m submitting my formal application and would be very happy to accept a place if offered. Our family values a warm, structured environment and we’re ready to complete any required paperwork promptly. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is Nursery_B, so I should apply immediately. Although Nursery_B ranks me relatively low (behind Parent_E, Parent_B, Parent_C), applying now maximizes my chance before it tentatively holds someone else. I will submit a clear, committed application emphasizing fit and readiness to accept if offered.

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_D,

Thank you very much for your application and for sharing why Nursery_B is your first choice. After reviewing applications received this round and given our limited capacity, we’re not able to offer you a place at Nursery_B.

We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best with your nursery placement.

Sincerely,
Nursery_B Admissions
conversation.thought: Parent_D is applying, but my true priority ranking is E > B > C > D > A. In this round I also received applications from Parent_C and Parent_A. Among these three, Parent_C is ranked higher than Parent_D, and I have only 1 seat. Parent_E (my top choice) has not applied to me and in fact ranks me last, so they are unlikely to come later. To maximize my outcome, I should avoid committing to Parent_D now and preserve capacity for Parent_C (who is applying now and ranks me first). Therefore I reject Parent_D.

Securing Parent_C now dominates waiting and risking ending up with a lower-priority match (Parent_A) or remaining unmatched. Therefore, accept Parent_C.
